article.title: A refined analysis of the low-mass eclipsing binary system T-Cyg1-12664

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the upper panel of Figure 1 show?
choices: The raw Kepler data for T-Cyg1-12664.
A fit of a Legendre polynomial to the Kepler data.
The residuals of the fit to the Kepler data.
Both a) and b)

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the detrending process applied to the Kepler light curve data?
choices: To remove the effects of instrumental systematics and spot-related activity.
To highlight the primary and secondary eclipses.
To calculate the orbital period of the system.
To measure the radial velocity of the stars.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 demonstrate about the effective temperature of T-Cyg1-12664?
choices: The effective temperature is consistent with a spectral type of K5V.
The effective temperature is better estimated at 5560±160 K.
The effective temperature measured by Çakırlı et al. (2013) is more accurate.
The effective temperature is not affected by stellar variability.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the systematic offset of secondary eclipses from phase 0.5 in Figure 4 indicate?
choices: The binary system has a circular orbit.
The binary system is experiencing apsidal motion.
The binary system has a slightly eccentric orbit.
There is a third body present in the system.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main source of uncertainty in the Teff estimates derived from temperature-color relations?
choices: Interstellar reddening.
Stellar variability.
Uncertainties in the color indexes.
The choice of temperature-color relation.
